fields.description:
FreeIPA 3.x is a very powerful replacement for MS AD. As it turns out, it also contains a full RBAC system that has host-based differentiation capabilities.

Imagine: Individual permissions allow very granular mapping to actual functions in the Atlassian stack. Traditional Atlassian roles such as jira-administrator allow a smooth migration path for existing users. Privileges are created to map these permissions to roles. Add hosts to the mix, and roles can be differentiated by server such that the jira-administrator role can be the same everywhere, but with only certain users available to exercise a role per host.  

FreeIPA does all this out of the box. 

Crowd is great, but FreeIPA has slowly improved to where Crowd was originally going to go. FreeIPA is incredibly detailed, maybe too detailed for the beginner user. As it's turned out, they compliment each other quite remarkably! Supporting both Crowd and FreeIPA will make the Atlassian stack incredibly valuable.
fields.summary: Support FreeIPA Roles/Permissions/Privileges

fields.description:
CWD-4084 introduced downstream synchronisation for "synch." group attributes.

When "synch.*" group attributes are stored into a caching directory, the operation succeeds, the attributes are saved in the cached and not written through to the remote dir. As a result, the attributes are temporarily visible, but they are removed from the cache by the next full sync.
fields.summary: "synch." group attributes are ephemerally stored in a caching directory

fields.description:
Our Crowd server is using an OpenLDAP server as it's sole source of Group memberships. Sometimes (about 1 out of every 30-50 changes to membership) when group membership is updated in LDAP, Crowd fails to recognize that update. Synchronizing the cache, or disabling the cache, both fail to resolve this problem.

However, if the Group membership is edited so that another member is added/deleted from the group, then Crowd will detect that group membership has changed and Crowd will update it's group memberships to accurately reflect the true list of group members.
fields.summary: Group memberships not being updated from LDAP

fields.description:
Any plans to implement a two factor authentication module for crowd?

Specifically [TOTP - RFC6238| http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-based_One-time_Password_Algorithm]

This would require an extra field or a way to pass an additional parameter for authentication as well as some set of options of on token parameters, and some additional flow for provisioning users.

fields.description:
The SSO cookie set by Confluence/Crowd ("crowd.token_key") is set to expire at session end, after the browser is quit.

This disables any and all "Remember me" checkboxes the users check in Confluence and people have to re-login after each browser start.

The token stays in the database, yes, but the *cookie* set by either crowd or confluence and jira (since they all use the same lib) has a expiry time of "session", meaning the cookie with the token inside is gone as soon as the user closes the browser. This obviously happens in any browser.

*The steps to reproduce/see this issue is:*
a) Crowd 2.7.2+
b) Confluence using a Crowd dictionary + the SSO authenticator in {{seraph-config.xml}} is configured properly: {code}<authenticator class="com.atlassian.confluence.user.ConfluenceCrowdSSOAuthenticator"/>{code}

Any cookie (by default, it's named "crowd.token_key") set when logging in to a) or b) will not have a MaxAge= parameter set. The code to see this is in {{atlassian-crowd/components/crowd-integration-client-common/*/CrowdHttpTokenHelperImpl.java in line 188/buildCookie()}}, which generates a standard servlet Cookie that has no MaxAge value set.

As said, the net effect is that SSO sessions are "lost" to the browser as soon as the user restarts his browser, and he has to re-login even if the server side session still persists.
fields.summary: SSO Cookie Expires at Session End Instead of Configured Timeout

fields.description:
When deleting a group from Crowd, the group is not removed from the "Default Group Memberships" option, under the directory.

*Steps to reproduce:*
# Create a user directory on Crowd (connector for example)
# After saving this directory, create a new local group pointing to this directory you've just created
# Then, go back to the directory created and select the _Options_ tab
# Add the group you've created
# Go under your _Groups_ on Crowd and delete the group you've created
# Go back to the directory created and select the _Options_ tab again
# The group still there
fields.summary: Removing group on Crowd keeps the group under "Default Group Memberships"

fields.description:
The fix for CWD-4011 involved a change to the RestExecutor to work around this upstream bug: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HTTPCLIENT-1542

Unfortunately the workaround goes too far and relativises the URL when talking to a proxy.

Either fix the workaround or upgrade to a version of HttpComponents containing the fix (4.3.6 or later) and remove it.
fields.summary: Crowd Rest client uses relative URL when revalidating http request even when talking to a proxy

	at org.springframework.ldap.transaction.compensating.manager.TransactionAwareDirContextInvocationHandler.invoke(TransactionAwareDirContextInvocationHandler.java:92) 
	at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy2058.getAttributes(Unknown Source) 
	at org.springframework.ldap.core.LdapTemplate$17.executeWithContext(LdapTemplate.java:937) 
	at org.springframework.ldap.core.LdapTemplate.executeWithContext(LdapTemplate.java:807) 
	... 19 more 
{quote}

I was able to reproduce what I think is the same problem with ApacheDS and some help from the debugger. Reproduction steps:

1. Set up ApacheDS with some users and groups
2. In Confluence configure the user directory
3. Attach the debugger and set a breakpoint in AbstractCacheRefresher#synchroniseMemberships. I put the break point on like 121, after the call to getMemberships(groupsByName.keySet());, but before the code has started iterating through the memberships collection.
4. In confluence synchronise the directory
5. Wait for your breakpoint to be hit
6. Now delete one of the groups form your LDAP directory
7. Now allow the process to continue
8. Observe that the synchronisation fails with LDAP error code 32.
fields.summary: Deleting a group during synchronisation leads to error 32 and synchronisation will not complete

fields.description:
In OnDemand, the Crowd Base URL is configured as http://localhost/crowd/service/

During RestExecutor initialisation the maximum connections per route is [configured|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/crowd/src/80bc90d96c29bd123869d2185e086b0c79832749/components/crowd-integration-client-rest/src/main/java/com/atlassian/crowd/integration/rest/service/RestExecutor.java#cl-141] for the route "http://localhost" to be 20. There's a subtle problem with this though. When actually issuing a request to Horde, the HttpRoute becomes "http://localhost:80", which is treated differently, and falls back to the default maximum connections per route of 2.

It looks like INST-2 introduced this issue, when they updated the Icebat to explicitly hack the CROWD_SERVER_BASE_URL [in each services run file|https://bitbucket.org/hoist/icebat/src/95b8fba6913af5fe3be18c78377d6e55fb22e3ad/modules/confluence/templates/run.erb?at=master#cl-80]. /cc [~cchauvet]

Ultimately this looks like it might actually be an Apache HttpClient bug. In debugging I noticed that the outbound request is definitely "http://localhost/crowd/foo", but after it passes through all the various HttpClient "*Exec" steps it ends up as "http://localhost:80/crowd/foo".
fields.summary: RestCrowdClient http.max.connections doesn't take effect when the base URL doesn't include a port

fields.description:
There's a scenario where default Crowd group memberships will not sync over to Confluence/JIRA during initial login. If Confluence/JIRA has synced with Crowd _prior_ to the user logging in to Confluence/JIRA, the user will be placed into the correct groups in Crowd but not in Confluence/JIRA.

h4. Steps to reproduce
# Inside Crowd: create an internal Crowd directory. In the 'Options' tab, set it to add users to some default groups upon initial authentication
# Inside Crowd: create a user in the internal directory but do not place him in groups
# Inside Confluence or JIRA: create a Crowd Server directory, and trigger a synchronization from Crowd
# Inside Confluence or JIRA: log in using the Crowd user

h4. Expected result
* User is added to default groups in Crowd
* User is added to the same default groups in Confluence

h4. Actual result
* User is added to default groups in Crowd (/)
* User is NOT added to any groups in Confluence (x)

This is alleviated during the next FULL sync from Confluence/JIRA, whether automatic or triggered manually. However, incremental syncs will NOT sync the membership info over, thus creating a discrepancy between Crowd and Confluence/JIRA.

h4. Workaround
* Restart Confluence/JIRA. This will trigger a full sync from Crowd on application startup
* Or, if the Crowd Server user directory is set to use full sync (the incremental sync option is unchecked), you can trigger a sync manually to get the memberships over
fields.summary: Default Crowd group memberships not added to JIRA/Confluence if directory sync has occurred

fields.description:
Noticed this tiny UI issue in 2.8 and 2.9 but it's probably in earlier versions as well.

When syncing from a remote directory, the display of the "Started" time on the "View Directory" screen takes inconsistent formats - sometimes it's in 12-hour format without time-zone suffix; other times it's in 24-hour format with time-zone suffix. Haven't established a pattern of its behaviour but it appears that turning off/on incremental sync will make it easier to trigger the swinging between the 2 formats.

Please see attached a screen-cast for details.
fields.summary: Inconsistent date/time formats on screen when syncing directory

fields.description:
* add an optional expand parameter to REST group search: "attributes"
* syncing attributes will be any attribute with a name starting with "synch."
* on full synchronisation of a Remote Crowd directory, ensure that all group attributes beginning with "synch." are made to reflect the remote directory
** any that exist internally, but not in the remote will be removed
** any that don't exist internally, but do in the remove will be added
** any that have differing values will be updated to the remote value
* on incremental synchronisation of a Remote Crowd directory, apply any changes to group attributes beginning with "synch."
* only Remote Crowd directories will sync group attributes
* this does not apply to User attributes
* this does not apply to attributes that do not start with "synch."

This feature is so that we can make meaningful changes to groups within the parent Crowd that can be reflected in the child applications.
fields.summary: Sync-able Group attributes from Remote Crowd directories

Changing the timeout  from the crowd or the application will affect all the user which might not suitable for some organization requirement.

fields.description:
Currently database password is stored in plain text format in crowd_home/crowd.cfg.xml file property “hibernate.connection.password”

Crowd should Encrypt the database password since it's in plain text in the crowd.cfg.xml l file or it could use the integrated authentication with the databases such as MSSQL database.
fields.summary: Encrypt Database Password in crowd.cfg.xml or use integrated authentication

fields.description:
LDAP connections over SSL are not pooled, meaning each operation acquires a new TCP connection as well as negotiating SSL. This significantly increases the time taken for operations like synchronisation.

For a default Crowd with no pooling configuration changes, synchronisation is single threaded, so only a single connection is made. (In testing, two connections; it's not clear if that's due to multiple threads or a single connection only being reused so many times.)

In terms of impact, a synchronisation with OpenLDAP that took 1m45 without SSL took as much as 8m15 when SSL was enabled.

Fixing this may require CWD-2790.
fields.summary: Pool SSL LDAP connections

fields.description:
Since Crowd 2.7, applications can use the {{key}} attribute on UserEntity in Crowd's REST APIs to identify a user across renames (including fetching a user by key using the key query param instead of the username query param).

We should update our developer documentation to reflect this once we are satisfied this part of our API is stable enough for clients to rely on.
fields.summary: Document UserEntity's "key" in REST API

fields.description: When upgrading Crowd, you download a new installation directory and point it at your old home directory. Unfortunately, the OpenID Server's database is stored in the installation directory, so needs to be manually copied across otherwise all the data is lost.

fields.description: Some operations in Crowd use a cascading classloader of context and application, even when they're operations that run asynchronously. Since all classes are part of the Crowd application there's no reason to use the context classloader: simplify these cases.
fields.summary: Use the application classloader more for consistency

fields.description:
Since two weeks it does not occur anymore that crowd notifies the user by email when their password are about to expire. (normal case: 1st mail three days before, 2nd two days and last one 1 day before). I didn't find any conspicuous event in our logs and have no idea why this changed just overnight?! 
Also very strange - I cant find a template for this notification in our "Mail Templates". I can only find two templates, one for "Forgotten Password " and another one for "Forgotten Username(s)" this missing one for Password Expiration" should be located there, too - right? 

So, how can I fix this problem or at least find the root cause?
Following an old mail I've received before we got this problem:

*Subject: Intranet password expires in 3 days
Hello X
Your intranet password (required for XX Login, XXX, Intranet Tools & ...) is about to expire in 3 days.
Please go to http://crowd.netstream.ch login with your current username / password and change your password right now

Thank you! - Your System Administrator*


- Crowd version: 2.6.4
fields.summary: Missing mail notification for password expiration

fields.description:
I'm supporting crowd2-plugin for jenkins and refactorting it atm. I found that crowd.properties and ClientProperties doesn't contain "secure" field for configuring https://docs.atlassian.com/crowd/2.7.1/com/atlassian/crowd/model/authentication/CookieConfiguration.html
Seems that this value should be part of configuration for applications.

p.s. 1) Is there some analog for SOAP based HttpAuthenticator.verifyAuthentication(username, password, validationFactors) using rest library that can easily return token?
2) Probably crowdClient may return configured tokenHelper. Then tokenHelper will have clientProperties and CookieConfiguration for setCrowdToken() with less arguments.
fields.summary: secure field for sso cookie isn't configurable from ClientProperties || crowd.properties

fields.description:

Therefore, to deactivate a user based on the application that is connected to would be useful as the deactivation would not be happen globally.

fields.description:
At the time of writing, Crowd is using the same version bundled in the AUI flatpack (1.8.3). However, there have been many releases since then - the latest 1.x release being 1.11.1.

We should update the version of jQuery we use. Do note, however, that we may need to include the {{jquery-migrate-plugin}} for backwards compatibility (since they removed a lot of deprecated APIs from jQuery core and into the plugin). In the {{atlassian-plugins-jquery}} plugin, this is already included.

In doing so, we should also stop using the version of jQuery bundled in the AUI flatpack and start using our own (we use the flatpack on setup screens and in a few other places).
fields.summary: Update jQuery to latest 1.x

2 elements have the same ID

fields.description:
*Setup:*
Requires crowd 2.8.0-rc1 installed along with the demo application.

*Steps:*
* Add two internal directories, {{dir1}} and {{dir2}}.
* Add groups to {{dir1}} -> {{group1}}, and {{dir2}} -> {{group2}}
* Ensure "Directory Aggregation" is enabled for the Demo application
* Add a user {{test}} to both {{dir1}} and {{dir2}}
* Make {{test}} part of {{group1}} and {{group2}}
* Add {{dir1}} and {{dir2}} to the {{demo}} application ({{dir1}} has priority)
* Add {{group2}} to the groups of the {{demo}} app.
* Now try and log into the demo app as {{test}}

*Result:*
User {{test}} cannot log in

*Expected result:*
User {{test}} can log in.

fields.description:
Here's an example of what this request would be:

If a user named *user1@example.com* tries to log in to JIRA, then Crowd will send the following search query to LDAP: 
{code}(&(<Crowd object filter>)(uid=user1@example.com)){code}

This search typically takes around 50 ms for a result. By moving the uid to the front of the search, like this:

{code}(&(uid=user1@example.com)(<Crowd object filter>)){code}

The response time drops to around 5 ms. More importantly it would avoid the un-indexed LDAP searches that correlate with users being unable to log in to our Atlassian applications.

With the information above, this is a request to Crowd be made to swap the order of object filter and uid in the search query it sends to LDAP.
fields.summary: Use uid first when combining uid and object filter when authenticating to LDAP for Improving Response Time

fields.description: Due to CWD-3225, queries can be expensive to evaluate even if they are paginated. Change the query to use one that is guaranteed to be inexpensive; the point is to test the connection, not the query results.

fields.description:
The methods in {{DirectoryManagerGeneric}} accept a directory ID and repeatedly uses {{DirectoryDao.findById(long)}} to look it up.  While this is a cached lookup in JIRA's implementation (and presumably for the other applications as well), it is unnecessary repeated effort.

Worse still, all of our caching solutions like to maintain statistics on the cache's hit/miss rate, and the synchronization constructions to protect the safety of maintaining these statistics can actually become a contention point when, as here, it's always the same key being used.  This is demonstrably a contributing factor for larger customers, particularly those that use nested groups.  For example, one of our JIRA Data Center customers recorded this profile in New Relic:

!CrowdDirectoryDaoAssault.png!

Using nested groups aggravates this quite a bit, because it recurses, each time looking up the directory only to throw it away again.  It would be a very simple matter to factor out private versions of these methods that accept a `Directory` instead of the directory ID and can therefore avoid looking it up multiple times when group membership doesn't cross directory boundaries, anyway.
fields.summary: DirectoryManagerGeneric unnecessarily abuses DirectoryDao

fields.description:
In Crowd, we have the option to limit the synchronisation to happen from an specific number of time (which would result in the days/hours needed). 

This is a feature request to schedule specific times for a directory to sync. For example, everyday at 7am, instead of inserting the minutes for the sync.
fields.summary: Schedule Specific Time for Directory Synchronisation

fields.description:
When a crowd application has multiple directories added to it, and a group which is authorised to log into Crowd, all directories with that group are allowed to log in to crowd. However, the UI makes it seem as though only a group in the chosen directory is allowed to log in.

Steps to reproduce:
* Add multiple directories to the crowd application "dir1", "dir2".
* Add a group to both directories with the same name "group"
* Add a user "test" to "dir2" with group "group".
* Add the group "group" from "dir1" to have access to crowd.
* Log in via user "test"

Result:
"test" user can log in.

Expected:
"test" user does not have permissions to log in.
fields.summary: Crowd gives more admin permissions than is apparent

fields.description:
Crowd 2.7 maps groups to crowd so that all directories mapped to the crowd application with the given group can log in. Note that the UI makes this unclear -- It will list the group as:
bq. <directory name> - <group name>
when in reality, all directories have access to the group.

Crowd 2.8 fixes this behaviour, so only the listed groups in the listed directories have administration or system administration access to crowd. Unfortunately, this can cause incongruous behaviour when upgrading, as several users who could previously log in as system administrator can no longer do so under Crowd 2.8.

To fix this, when upgrading from Crowd 2.7 to 2.8, all groups in all directories which had practically had access to Crowd administration in 2.7 should explicitly gain access in 2.8. This can later be removed by crowd administrators if desired.
fields.summary: Ease permissions transition from crowd 2.7 to 2.8
Allow adding a UserWithAttributes through CrowdService

fields.description:
Setup:

2) Using the SingleSignOn Connector from seraph-config.xml
3) crowd is connected to OpenLDAP (also r/w)

Steps to reproduce:
1) Delete a user, which has active group memberships, in jira
2) Create a user with the same name in jira

Problem:

2) After the recreation, the former group memberships are "restored" (in crowd and in jira)

May somehow be related to https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-25611 , however it seems not to be fixed so far.

Kind regards,

Sebastian Lotter
fields.summary: Group membership leak after user recreation

fields.description:
{{SpringLDAPConnector.testConnection}} acquires an {{LdapContext}} to confirm that the connection works, but doesn't close it. This means it's left open until garbage collection, which may not be immediate.

This is not likely to cause production issues, as this method is called infrequently.
fields.summary: LDAP connection testing can leave connections open until GC

bq. curl https://jdog.jira-dev.com/admin/rest/um/1/user/search?max-results=31&userFilters=users

Whereas this takes ~1 second:

bq. curl https://jdog.jira-dev.com/admin/rest/um/1/user/search?max-results=31

To reproduce this go to https://jdog.jira-dev.com/admin/users and click the "Users" filter.

!filter users.png!
fields.summary: Request for "Users" is super slow

fields.description:
We've experienced authentication problems in Confluence with most of the users getting *Not Permitted* after logging in. 
That's the chronology of the events: 
* Problems were detected after the last synchronisation with Crowd
* We checked the Crowd logs and we found there had been some connection problems whilst connecting the AD. At that moment only 300 users seemed to belong to the _confluence-users_ group.
* We fixed the network issues and after next synchronisation the around 2000 users were back to _confluence-users_ group.
* However, a small set of users remained corrupted and unable to access Confluence with the same error.
* After further analysis of those users we found out the users had listed _confluence-users_ group but checking the group itself to see the members those users were not appearing.
* After synchronising again and restarting Confluence clearing caches that was fixed.

Our configuration:
* Nested groups enabled
* Cache disabled in Crowd
* Incremental Sync enabled in Confluence

We've been able to reproduce this behaviour in a test environment by simulating loss of packages in the Crowd server.

Some consistency checking should be in place to inform group memberships are corrupted.
fields.summary: Group memberships corruption after network issues connecting to the Active Directory
